passages.text: August 31, 2025 09:00 PM GMT

CGPI is among India's most diversified capital goods players. It has a strong presence in manufacturing (motors franchise) & is a beneficiary of strong growth in power (transformers & switchgears). Further, it aims to build capabilities in critical sectors like semis & railways. Initiate at OW.

Industrials: Revenue & EBIT CAGRs (F25- 28e) of \(14\%\) & \(15\%\) , respectively. Power systems: Revenue & EBIT CAGRs (F25- 28e) of \(35\%\) & \(42\%\) , respectively. Semiconductors: Peak asset turns of \(1.9x\) by F31e.

Macro remains constructive: India's initiatives to increase manufacturing's share of GDP (which we note will drive demand for motors & drives) will spur power demand (also helped by more use cases for electricity, like AI) amid growing renewable energy (RE) penetration (driving demand for grid equipment - scale, stability & modernization), helping to reduce India's dependence on imported energy (amid increased use of electric locomotives across passenger & freight trains, as well as electric vehicles (EVs)) and improve living conditions (investing in passenger safety via KAVACH), further supported by a domestic semiconductor manufacturing revival.

CGPI - A core India manufacturing holding: CGPI's manufacturing prowess supports its earnings growth potential and ability to generate cash flows - creating strong moats that we believe yield favorable competitive positioning relative to its MNC capital goods peers. The stock offers key exposure to manufacturing via CGPI's motors division, where it has a dominant market franchise and strong capacity- led growth in power systems - aCROSS power transformers, distribution transformers, and switchgears. Further, in its younger businesses, like railways, CGPI has increased its product portfolio (originally & inorganically), and it is incubating a semiconductor division (organic capex: outsourced semiconductor assembly and test (OSAT) + inorganic+ semis design).

Initiate at OW, PT Rs799: We value the: 1) core business (ex- semis) at 60x Sep- 27e P/E (in line with its MNC capital goods peers) at Rs771/share, and 2) semis business at Rs28 share using DCF (Ke: \(12.4\%\) (beta: 1, RF: \(6.4\%\) ), and terminal growth: \(3\%\) ). We forecast core earnings (ex- semis) to rise at a \(30\%\) CAGR, F25- 28e. Earnings growth should be supported by its capacity addition plans across the motors, transformers and switchgear segments, in addition to increased ordering by railways. We expect EBIT contribution of the power- system segment to rise from \(48\%\) in F25 to \(57\%\) in F28e. At our PT, the stock would trade at 62x Sep- 27 P/E (a \(7\%\) discount to its 3- year average). Key risks include: 1) rising competitive intensity in transformers, 2) prices and demand for motors stay low or decline further, 3) sluggish execution in railways, and 4) OSAT business fails to pick up on execution and/or margin.
MORGAN STANLEY INDIA COMPANY PRIVATE LIMITED+
CG Power and Industrial Solutions Ltd. (CGPO.NS,
India Industrials | India

India's Manufacturing Proxy

CGPI is among India's most diversified capital goods players, with market leadership in most of its segments. Most of its capital goods peers are focused on select end- verticals, which makes growth avenues more dispersed for CGPI.
It has a strong presence in manufacturing (motors franchise) & is a beneficiary of strong growth in power systems. It aims to build capabilities in critical sectors, e.g., semis & railways.
CGPI's moats include manufacturing prowess, which supports earnings growth & ability to generate FCF. This makes its relative competitive positioning comparable to its MNC capital goods peers.
Our forecast of \(34\%\) PAT CAGR, F25- 28e, is the fastest in our EPC/cap goods coverage.
Source: Refinitiv, Morgan Stanley Research

a) India's government has enacted some key initiatives to boost manufacturing, including 1) "Make in India" (2014), with a focus on 25 sectors, 2) Phased Manufacturing Programme (PMP; 2017), 3) corporate tax reduction (2019), 4) Atmanirbhar Bharat Abhiyan (self-reliant India, during Covid-19), and 5) Production Linked Incentive Schemes (PLI; 2020), across 14 strategic sectors, with an outlay of Rs2trn.

b) Further, the government has focused on infrastructure creation through policy initiatives such as 1) national infrastructure pipeline (2020), 2) Bharatmala Pariyojana (national highway program; 2017), 3) Sagarmala Project (port capacity & modernization), 4) UDAN (Ude Desh Ka Aam Nagarik) Scheme (regional airport connectivity), 5) BharatNet (digital infrastructure), 6) PM Gati Shakti (National master plan for infrastructure, 2021), 7) national rail plan (2022), and 8) national logistics policy (2022). These efforts also incorporate measures to clear bottlenecks to smooth development in the manufacturing sector.

c) Separately, the government has also created sector-specific manufacturing initiatives, such as in: a) electronics & semiconductors: 1) PLI schemes (6 out of 14 sectors; 2020), 2) India's Semiconductor Mission (2021), and 3) Electronic Component Manufacturing Scheme (2025); b) Defense Manufacturing (import substitution); and c) offering incentives/local manufacturing regulations for backward integration into the RE energy value chain (import substitution & export promotion).

Core business - Strong motors franchise & sweet spot for power: CGPI has a dominant market franchise in industrial motors with \(\sim 38\%\) in low tension (LT) motors, \(\sim 20\%\) in high tension (HT) motors, and \(\sim 35\%\) share in fractional-horsepower motor (FHP) motors in F24. The key demand drivers for this segment include capacity additions (CGPI is in the process of doubling its current capacity by Q1F27), increased adoption of energy-efficient motors (replacement demand), rising penetration of electric vehicles (EV motors & controllers), adoption of industrial drives, and CGPI's increasing focus on increasing exports. In addition, CGPI's power segment is in a sweet spot, as macro (investments in grid, driven by scale & modernization, as well as for stability with rising RE penetration) is conducive for continued demand momentum - and CGPI's capacity additions across power transformers (medium, high and extra-high voltage), distribution transformers, and switchgears should spur earnings growth.

Building capabilities in critical sectors, such as semis & railways: In rail, CGPI has added its product capabilities both organically & inorganically through its acquisition of G.G. Tronics in August 2024, which gave it access to KAVACH (electronic safety signalling systems) - India's indigenous Train Collision Avoidance System (ATP). CGPI is also investing Rs76bn to set up an outsourced semiconductor assembly and testing (OSAT) facility in Gujarat (project approved in February 2024), and, in October 2024, it acquired the radio frequency business of Renesas Electronics America Inc, which is now housed under CGPI's Axiro division. CGPI is working to build a semiconductor platform under Axiro through multiple acquisitions.
CGPI is among India's most diversified capital goods players: CGPI has diversified

product offerings, with market leadership in most of its segments. CGPI's manufacturing prowess covers industrial motors & drives, power transformers, distribution transformers, switchgears, railway equipment, FMEG products, and semiconductor packaging, among other segments. CGPI has also established strong relationships with its customers across several sectors, including in cement, metals and mining, power, renewables, nuclear, oil and gas, railways and metros, pulp and paper, sugar and ethanol, water and waste- water management, chemical and fertilizers, agriculture, telecoms, materials handling, pharmaceuticals, and automotive. Most of CGPI's industrial peers have a business that is heavy in either motors, transformers, railways, engines & gen- sets, defense equipment, renewable equipment, or bearings, and, in some cases, some combination of the above segments. Thus, CGPI is distinctively positioned given its diverse businesses.

Understanding CGPI's business strategy: Key components of CGPI's strategy include: 1) operational excellence: efforts to optimise plant capacities and horizontal deployment of best practices; 2) commercial excellence: utilising product management tools to enhance wallet share / penetrate new customers; 3) invest in R&D: become future- ready and align with the voice of customers; 4) geographical diversification: focus on exports to expand footprint & strengthen position on the international stage; 5) service/spares business mix: improve recurring revenue, customer stickiness, and margins; 6) expand & optimize asset base: capacity expansion & optimization to address future growth and profit pool; and 7) diversify business into high- growth sectors, such as semiconductors.
Exhibit 8: CGPI: Key drivers and challenges across businesses
Source: Morgan Stanley Research.
Multiple optionalities that could drive a stronger earnings CAGR: We see multiple growth optionalities across CGPI's businesses. For instance:

1. Motors: A strong pickup in exports, domestic demand for EV motors & controllers, and stronger adoption of CGPI's drives offering could drive growth ahead of our base case estimates.  
2. Railways: CGPI targets 20% market share in Indian railways' KAVACH program. If the award cycle picks up, this could result in strong earnings progression. Growth could also strengthen if CGPI's exports strategy bears fruit.  
3. Power systems: CGPI is open to adding transformer capacity, given strong domestic & international demand.  
4. FMEG: CGPI can look to expand this portfolio to more product segments. In F25, CGPI launched 50 new SKUs and expanded its presence across e-commerce platforms, regional chain stores, and modern retail formats  
5. Inorganic route: CGPI can also undertake value-accretive acquisitions across its business segments, as it would be left with a strong cash balance, even post committed investments for OSAT. CGPI management has highlighted it remains opportunistic for inorganic growth opportunities to grow its market share, enter new markets, diversify its product portfolio, improve operational efficiency, and enhance expertise and knowledge.

**CGPI - we are OW relative to our Industrials coverage:** CGPI's manufacturing prowess supports earnings growth potential and ability to generate cash flows, creating strong moats that we believe yield favorable competitive positioning relative to its MNC capital goods peers. Further, the sectors CGPI is exposed to have strong tailwinds for growth. Also, CGPI's 34% PAT CAGR, F25-28e, is the fastest in our EPC/cap goods coverage. CGPI has diversified product offerings, with market leadership in most of its segments. Also most of its capital goods peers are focused on select end-verticals, which makes growth avenues more dispersed for CGPI.

**Where we could go wrong: 1) Motors: sluggish volume growth + pricing pressure +** weaker margins; 2) Transmission: capex at capital goods competitors bears fruit earlier than expected, or supply & demand, driving margins below our current forecasts; 3) slower execution of exports strategy; 4) customer acquisitions are weaker than expected in its OSAT business; and 5) railway margins continue to disappoint as suppliers (like CGPI) do not have complete ability to pass on inflation to Indian railways (customer), despite the price variation clause (PVC), as the formula fails to work efficiently.

Growth of India's electrical equipment sector: The market has risen at a steady \(6\%\) CAGR, C19- 24, in value terms, which was \(\sim 1x\) India's GDP growth, driven by increasing demand for automation, efficiency, and energy management across various industries. Key themes driving sector growth remain manufacturing ("Make in India", Atmanirbhar Bharat), energy management (sustainability, investments in renewables, power T&D) and automation (technology advancements, industry 4.0).

» Demand drivers for motors: These include: a) growth in existing avenues, such as in manufacturing, construction, motion, cooling requirements, appliances, water & sanitation, and machinery, as well as in newer avenues, such as rising penetration of EVs and

automation; and b) need for increased energy efficiency drives replacement demand to more advanced motors and adoption of drives for variable speed motors. India's motors segment rose at a 5% CAGR pre-Covid, F15-19, in value terms. The Indian Electrical & Electronics Manufacturers' Association (IEEMA) expects motor sales to rise at a 7-8% CAGR over the next five years.

Exhibit 17: Energy efficiency benefits of motors

Energy efficiency to drive replacement cycle: The International Energy Association (IEA) suggests that motors account for \(\sim 70\%\) of industrial electricity consumption. Hence, efficient power consumption is imperative from an emissions control standpoint. As per ABB, with each efficiency class improvement, the energy losses are lower by \(15 - 20\%\) , and ABB estimates that globally, there are \(300\mathrm{nm + }\) industrial motors in operation currently, which if replaced with energy- efficient motors could reduce power consumption by up to \(10\%\) .

Industries such as automotive, manufacturing, and infrastructure are increasingly integrating these technologies to strengthen their sustainability efforts and meet ESG commitments. Technological advancements in motor design and increased domestic manufacturing capabilities are accelerating this shift, fostering a competitive market for high- efficiency motors and reducing India's reliance on imports.
for high- efficiency motors and reducing India's reliance on imports.

The implementation of IE3 motors as the minimum efficiency standard has been propelled by India government policies, phasing out the less- efficient IE1 and IE2 motors. Bureau of Energy Efficiency (BEE) initiatives focus on promoting energy conservation and reducing emissions, helping to promote widespread compliance with IE3 standards. In India, IE2 motors constitute the largest pie - viz. \(\sim 50 - 55\%\) of the mix in F25 - while IE3 motors account for \(30 - 35\%\) , and IE4 & IE5 motors account for \(10 - 15\%\) of the mix. The adoption of advanced IE4 & IE5 motors is also gaining momentum, offering improved energy savings, lower operational costs, and compliance with global efficiency standards.

Whilst energy- efficiency- related benefits are known and consumer awareness keeps improving, change in government regulations is a key driver to monitor. Further, ABB estimates that the global number of motors will double by 2040. Many European nations have moved to IE3 and IE4 motors.
Exhibit 18: Global standards on energy efficiency of motors
Source: ABB presentation dated Sep-24

> Rising penetration of EVs to aid growth: Motor content in an EV is higher compared to that in an ICE vehicle, with key motor components forming \(\sim 15\%\) of the vehicle costs. EV penetration in India has increased from \( Imperative to aid improving industrial efficiencies: Variable speed drives control and regulate the flow of power to motors by adjusting the frequency and the voltage. This effectively leads to efficient consumption of energy depending on usage ( \(\sim 25\%\) energy savings, per ABB). Further, motors connected to drives also have lower maintenance costs, can help reduce downtime, require lower maintenance, and create lower waste and noise. However, currently only \(\sim 20\%\) of motors globally are connected with a variable speed drive. We believe increased awareness and adoption of drives would offer a sizeable opportunity for their manufacturers (understanding the energy chain - ABB).

Electrical engineering equipment in the railways: Capital goods components in rail primarily contribute to the generation, distribution, and use of electrical power for train operations, signalling, and communication. These components are designed to ensure the reliable supply of power, enable precise control of train movements, and maintain communication across the network.

The integration of advanced electrical engineering equipment enhances the overall performance, safety, and sustainability of the railway sector. Electrical engineering equipment used in Indian railways have risen at a \(5\%\) revenue CAGR, C19- 24, and this is expected to rise at a \(7\%\) CAGR, C24- 29e, per CGPI QIP document.

> Indian Railways - Rolling India forward: Years of underinvestment in railways has reversed, amid stronger budgetary allocation in recent years. Average annual railway capex increased 5x in F21- 26BE (Budgetary Estimates) compared to the pre- 2014 average. Commissioning of dedicated freight corridors (DFC) is likely to enhance railways' freight share. In addition, the Ministry of Railways is looking to roll out three new rail corridors that, in turn, would open opportunities for wagons and locomotives. Renewed thrust on the passenger business, with new offerings (new Vande Bharat & Amrit Bharat trains and high- speed rail corridors) and improved amenities would drive rail capex spend. For more details, see our report, "The New India - Railways: Rolling India Forward" (6 May 2024).

India's Ministry of Railways is working on three new rail corridors spanning \(\sim 40,900\mathrm{kms}\) that would enable multi- modal connectivity, reduce costs, improve efficiencies, and ease the problem of passenger ticket waiting lists. Once implemented, these tracks would increase freight capacity to 3,000MT and passenger capacity to 10bn. These are expected to be built over the next eight years, with initial capex earmarked at Rs11trn. Furthermore, railways are set to locally procure \(>50\%\) of content for most products and \(>75\%\) for Vande Bharat trains, driving the localization theme.

> Propulsion systems: Propulsion systems form \(20 - 25\%\) of the passenger coach bill of materials (BOM; Source: Titagarh Rail Systems). Electric propulsion systems are predominant in Indian railways, with a sizeable portion of the network electrified to meet the growing demand for faster, cost- effective, and environmentally friendly transportation. These systems utilize electric traction motors powered by overhead lines through pantographs, supported by advanced control systems for enhanced efficiency and safety.

> Increasing focus on safety: Signalling in Indian Railways rose at a \(3\%\) revenue CAGR, C19- 24e, to US\$138mn, and per CGPi QIP document, the same is expected to rise at a \(5.7\%\) CAGR, F24- 29e, to US\$182mn, led by large- scale modernization initiatives (automatic train control, centralized traffic control, real- time monitoring systems). In addition, the government focus on improving safety, operational efficiency, and passenger experience, coupled with the drive for digitalization and smart rail solutions, should further support the growth trajectory.
Exhibit 23: Global: Electrical Equipment in the rail sector
Source: CGPi QIP document, Maia Research. Note: Forecasts are by Maia Research.

(1) Propulsion systems: This equipment accounts for the largest share in global electrical traction systems, at \(48.3\%\) of the overall electrical equipment in railways. Per CGPi QIP document, this segment is expected to rise at a \(5.7\%\) revenue CAGR, C24-29e, to US \$12bn by C29e, led by advancements in technology, growing adoption of electric and hybrid vehicles, and stricter regulatory norms promoting efficient and sustainable solutions.

(2) Traction systems: This equipment accounts for the second-largest share in global electrical traction systems, at \(\sim 25\%\) of the overall electrical equipment in railways. Per CGPi QIP document the same is expected to rise at a \(5.8\%\) revenue CAGR, C24-29e, to US\$6.4bn by C29e, driven by increasing electrification trends across various sectors, advancements in traction technologies, and a growing focus on energy-efficient systems.

(3) Signalling systems: As per CGPi QIP document, the global signalling systems is expected to rise at a \(5.6\%\) revenue CAGR, C24-29e, to US\$3bn. Growth will be driven by investments in digital signalling solutions, such as communications-based train control (CBTC) and European train control systems (ETCS), which improve system capacity and

operational efficiency. Additionally, the push towards green and sustainable transport solutions, coupled with government initiatives to upgrade public transportation systems, is expected to fuel further demand, according to CGPI QIP document.

Rising importance of grid equipment: India's energy sector is witnessing strong momentum, with the energy transition demanding all the relevant stakeholders to collaborate and take urgent action toward a more sustainable future for all. Transmission systems around the world need 're- wiring' as coal dependence is reduced – and hence need to connect to new sources of generation – like upcoming renewable and nuclear. Further, RE variability (weather linked) would give rise to grid issues unless the generated power is distributed over longer distances and to multiple demand centers via transmission lines and through use of automation. Moreover, there exists significant variation in demand on account of seasonal differences and time- of- day demand differences, which will necessitate large inter- regional transmission capacities to prevent grid fluctuations.

Role of transformers: The utilities sector relies heavily on power transformers to ensure the efficient transmission and distribution of electricity. Transformers regulate voltage and facilitate transfer of electricity from generation facilities to distribution substations and end- consumers. Transformers enable seamless electricity transfer over long distances, while minimizing losses and maintaining grid stability. Additionally, they enable utilities to manage load fluctuations, balance supply and demand, and adapt to changing consumption patterns. Transformers are thus critical electrical components to facilitate stronger integration of RE, grid interconnections, powering data centers (used for powering AI applications), and electrifying transportation.

Putting India's TAM in context: The Indian government estimates the country's power generation capacity (including RE & energy storage) to reach \(\sim 776GW\) in F30 (F24: 462GW). Further, India has a robust RE installation target of 500GW by 2030. Incremental capacity additions would be dominated by RE, and overall capacity additions would not evenly spread across India. This necessitates strong investments in T&D to support transfer of power generated (from source of generation to place of consumption) as well as grid stability. To add perspective, most RE additions will be in northern (likely Rajasthan), western, and southern India, and most thermal capacities will be in eastern & central India, closer to the coal mines. Transmission projects have been planned for major RE zones, such as the Leh RE park, Rajasthan, Gujarat, Andhra Pradesh, and offshore wind farms in Tamil Nadu and Gujarat.

The National Electricity Plan (NEP) pegs transmission capex at Rs9.2trn over F23- 32 (Rs4.25trn over F23- 27, and Rs4.9trn over F28- 32). Inter- state capex is pegged at Rs6.6trn, while the balance (Rs2.6trn) is toward intra- state. The NEP assumes peak demand of 296GW by F27, and 388GW by F32, respectively. As per the plan, the government targets to add 1,240GVA of non- HVDC transformation capacity (120% growth over F22) and 33,250MW of HVDC transformation capacity over F23- 32 (100% growth over F22).

To reduce the demand- supply mismatch caused by RE, the interregional power transfer capacity target stands has increased to 134GW by F30, as the share of inter- regional transmission capacity is expected by government to increase from 13.9% in F12 to 18.4% in
F29. Thus, several inter-regional transmission corridors have been planned; some of these high-capacity transmission corridors are in various stages of implementation.

The transformers segment has risen at a \(6\%\) CAGR, C19- 23, in value terms, and, as per CGPI QIP document, will potentially rise at a \(12\%\) CAGR, C23- 29e, driven by RE capacity additions, ageing grid infrastructure, industrialization, urbanization, rural electrification program, expansion of rail and metro networks, green- hydrogen- led transmission requirements, and emerging new- age industries of data centres, semiconductors, etc.

Further, India's PM Modi launched the Green Grids Initiative - One Sun One World One Grid (GGIOSOWOG) at COP26, the first international network of global interconnected solar power grids. The objective is to have globally interconnected power grid projects aimed at seamless sharing of RE among countries for mutual benefits and global sustainability. India's RE Ministry is the programme support agency for the OSOWOG initiative, International Solar Alliance (ISA) is the nodal implementing agency, and the World Bank is the strategic advisory and funding agency.

The size of India's electrical power equipment industry to rise at a \(13\%\) CAGR, C23- 29e: Rising power demand, expansion and strengthening of power network and systems, and increasing residential and industrial demand provide strong tailwinds for the industry.

The industry, pegged at \(\sim \mathsf{US}\$ 9bn\) in value terms, primarily comprises transformers ( \(\sim 40\%\) , power & distribution), switchgears ( \(\sim 32\%\) ), and circuit breakers ( \(\sim 10\%\) ). As per CGPI, the size of the transformers and switchgear market is expected to rise at a \(12\%\) CAGR, and the circuit breaker market is expected to rise at a \(13\%\) CAGR, C23- 29e, while others, including reactors, surge arrestors, transformers (locomotive & trackside) are expected to rise at a \(12\%\) CAGR, C23- 29e.

> Energy transition commitments: Under the Paris agreement, countries had pledged to keep the increase in global average temperature to well below \(2^{\circ}C\) and pursue efforts to limit it to \(1.5^{\circ}C\) . At COP28, participating countries committed to tripling the global RE installed base to \(>11,000GW\) , and to double the global average annual rate of energy efficiency improvements, from \(\sim 2\%\) to \(>4\%\) by 2030. Further, at COP29, the Global Grids Pledge was announced, calling for a significant increase in investment in grid infrastructure. One of the key points was committing to a global grid deployment goal of adding or refurbishing 25mn kms of grids and the deployment of 1,500GW of energy storage by 2030.

Multiple countries around the world are looking to modernize the grid, which involves significant investments in smart grid technologies, such as intelligent monitoring and control systems, automation, and grid optimization solutions. Such advancements enhance grid efficiency, reliability, and safety.

As per the IEA Announced Pledges Scenario (APS), over next two decades the length of the global grid will be \(>2x\) vs 2021, viz. 166mn km by 2050. Distribution accounts for \(>90\%\) , connecting billions of consumers, and the transmission grid would be 12.7mn km by 2050 (2021: 5.3mn km). Thus, over the next two decades, \(>80mn\) km of global transmission & distribution length would be either replaced or added. Interestingly, in the past five years, grid investments have been stable at \(\sim \mathsf{US}\$ 300bn / \mathsf{annum}\) ; this is likely to be \(\sim \mathsf{US}\$ 450bn\) during C21- 30 and US \(87bn\) during C41- 50.

» Understanding US dynamics: US power demand could remain strong, driven by GenAI, while power grid replacement ( \(>75\%\) of lines & transformers are \(>25\) years old), and growing RE energy conversion would drive growth for transformer manufacturers.

1. Power demand: IEA estimates US data centers' electricity consumption rate to rise from about 200 TWh in 2022 to almost 260 TWh by 2026, accounting for \(6\%\) of total electricity demand (from \(2.5\%\) in 2023).  
2. Power grid replacement: According to the US Energy Information Administration (EIA), as of 2021, over \(75\%\) of power equipment was outdated and will need to be replaced.  
3. RE integration into the power grid.  
4. \(\sim 80\%\) of the US transformer market relies on imports, mostly from global players such as Schneider, Siemens, ABB, and Eaton, with only \(\sim 20\%\) of US demand met by domestic supply.

\(\gg\) Rising use cases for switchgears, with grid expansions underway: Increasing RE penetration in the grid and an expanding network require stable power flow over longer distances, necessitating demand for controlling equipment/switchgears. Further, an increasing proportion of smart grid & automation adds to demand for power flow controlling/regulating devices. Switchgears of extra high, high, and medium voltage are used in transmission grids, while low voltage switchgears, used at the end- user point, will likely see strong demand, in our view. As per CGPl, the size of the medium- voltage, high- voltage, and extra- high- voltage (EHV) markets has grown at a \(7\%\) CAGR, C19- 24, and are expected to reach US \(1.83bn\) by C29 (11% CAGR).

\(\gg\) Increasing adoption of gas- insulated switch- gears: Use of gas- insulated switchgears in substations results in lower land requirements vs traditional substations with air- insulated switchgears. With increasing urbanization, despite the higher cost of GIS substations, there has been an increase in adoption. Further, with increasing environmental awareness of SF6 (the gas used for electrical insulation), some manufacturers have innovated ecofriendly technology and are aiming for replacement- led demand from the existing GIS systems.

» Indian OSAT market supported by government fiscal aid: The Indian OSAT market remains at a nascent stage. India's PM Modi aspires to have every device in the world contain an Indian- made chip. The government's objective thus remains to build an ecosystem, enhance self- reliance and de- risk from dependence on global supply chains. It aims to achieve this through a) corporates contributing via investments & increased value addition, and b) government facilitating the same through stable policies and improving the ease of doing business.

Fuelled by a combination of favourable factors, such as the growing demand for electronics, strong government support, expanding domestic electronics manufacturing, cost competitiveness, a skilled workforce, strategic proximity to end- markets, and the integration of emerging technologies, the Indian OSAT market is well positioned to become a key player in the global semiconductor industry, in our view. We believe that India has the potential to establish itself as a global leader in OSAT manufacturing, attracting prominent industry players and becoming a vital hub within the global semiconductor supply chain.

1. Motors: CGPl manufactures a range of low-tension (LT) motors (F24 domestic market share: \(38\%\) in value terms), high-tension (HT) motors, fractional horsepower (FHP) motors, and stampings.

2. Drives & automation: CGPl manufactures a wide range of drives and automation products to enhance industrial efficiency and control. CGPl's products include alternating current (AC) drives, direct current (DC) low-voltage drives, and medium-voltage drives, which are used to regulate motor speed and torque for optimized performance, as well as soft starters and shaft power monitors to ensure smooth operation and protect equipment.

3. Railways: CGPl manufactures rolling stock products & signalling products. Rolling stock products include propulsion systems for diesel and electric locomotives, traction motors, traction converters, auxiliary converters, train control monitoring system (TCMS), battery chargers, and electrics for multiple-unit trains, as well as signalling products that include relays, train collision avoidance system (TCAS) and multi section digital axle counter system (MSDAC).

4. FMEG: CGPl entered the fast-moving electrical goods (FMEG) segment with pumps & exhaust fans, and subsequently expanded into ceiling, table, pedestal, and wall fans, as well as instant and storage water heaters.

c) Drives - Large runway for growth: Drives have lower penetration compared to motors and hold significant potential in the domestic & overseas markets. Currently, many factories in India rely on electrical systems alone. With the right drive, an electric motor will adjust to the underlying load, leading to significant power savings. Drives control the speed of an AC motor by varying the frequency and voltage of the power being fed to it. When they are not controlled by a drive, many motors run at full speed even when the load requirements are minimal. The drives are an additional cost, but in the long term the efficiency, variance, accuracy, and energy savings that drives provide make them a cost-effective addition.

Globally, per ABB, only \(20\%\) of motors are connected with drives, leaving large scope for growing the integrated offerings, as there is a growing focus on energy efficiency, digitalization, and automation. Demand is also supported by increasing affordability and flexibility of operations. Further, emerging avenues, such as drives for green energy solutions, battery storage, hydrogen production, and solar manufacturing are adding to demand tailwinds.

In 2011, CGPI acquired Emotron (Sweden- based), which has manufacturing units in Sweden and Germany. Its four key segments are: Marine, Water and Wastewater, Green Energy Power Solutions, and Material Handling. CGPI had a \(5\%\) share in the domestic market as of September 2023. It continues to invest in R&D and currently has three manufacturing facilities (Sweden, Germany, and Bhopal) to cater to markets across India, the Nordic, Germany, Netherlands, MEA region, South Asia, Russia, South America, and more recently, in France and North America.

CGPI has low- voltage drives that are used in manufacturing, HVAC systems, and smaller industrial uses, and medium- voltage drives that are used in industries including oil and gas, mining, and heavy manufacturing. With the increased adoption of higher- efficiency variable- speed motors in India, we think CGPI can leverage its capabilities in variable- speed
drives to complement its motors offerings. We note that the profitability of its drives business has improved over the past three years.

The drives business has international approvals, including: 1) UK Conformity Assessed Marking (UKCA) for the UK market, 2) Secured revalidation of Nema Premium Certification for the American market; and 3) CSA approved certification for testing for the American market.

New segment: In F25, CG started to venture into newer areas like desalination plants, compressed biogas projects, and bidding for the government- run Energy Efficiency Services Limited (EESL) projects.

New products: a) Increase in penetration of EVs would create opportunities for parts such as traction motors, inverters and motor controllers, which differ from those in traditional ICE vehicles. CGPl has developed EV motors & controllers for the domestic market across 3- wheelers, LCVs, MCVs, HCVs, trucks, and buses. However, currently, its EV- related offerings are limited to smaller motors that would require technology advancement to make induction motors for EVs. CGPl's 'Smart Motor' Solution enables remote monitoring of motor operations and health, facilitating preventive maintenance. Currently, permanent magnet synchronous motors (PMSM), switch reduction, control synchronous motors, among others, are being tested by the company. The present PMSM technology uses rare earth elements.

b) CGPl has expanded its range of energy-efficient motors to include IE5 Ultra-premium Efficiency Synchronous Reluctance Motors. These motors have the potential to reduce energy losses & energy consumption by \(>50\%\) vs IE2 induction motors. These motors also do not use rare earth materials and have an environmentally friendly design. Further, these motors have a faster payback for improved operational profitability, precise speed and torque control, high efficiency across the entire speed range, lower winding and bearing temperatures for enhanced product life, faster accelerations due to low inertia, and reduced noise. They can be seamlessly upgraded to induction motors without requiring any mechanical modifications. These motors are suitable across applications such as HVAC, pumps, fans, compressors, and extruders.

CGPI's core competency in railways includes manufacturing of rolling stock products (propulsion systems for diesel and electric locomotives, traction motors, traction converters, auxiliary converters, train control monitoring systems, etc.), and signalling products (relays, TCAS, and MSDAC).

CGPI's rolling stock and signaling product portfolio consists of: a) traction machine and systems - AC & DC motors, alternators, solutions for self-propelled vehicles; b) traction electric - complete electrics, IGBT-based (insulated gate bipolar transistor) propulsion systems and panels; c) signalling - relays, point machines, data logger and coach products, such as panels and fans; and d) transformers - locomotives and track side.

New products: V connected - 132kV, 63MVA traction power transformers to support new catenary system of 2x27kV, designed for high-speed trains and to reduce transmission losses; and auto transformers of 55/2x27.5kV and 16.5MVA capacity to support high-speed infrastructure with reduced transmission losses.

GGT acquisition: CGPI acquired a \(55.6\%\) stake in G.G.Tronics (GGT) for Rs3.2bn in November 2024 through a combination of purchase of equity shares from GGT's promoters and subscription to compulsorily convertible Preference Shares that were subsequently converted into equity shares. The rationale for the acquisition was to expand CGPI's rail product portfolio. GGT manufactures digital axle counters (40- 45% market share, revenues of Rs1.1bn & profitable) and has recently started manufacturing TCAS - KAVACH or Automatic Train Protection Systems (IRATPS). GGT also has significant
capabilities in embedded systems and power electronics.

KAVACH - an introduction: KAVACH (electronic safety signaling systems) is India's indigenous Train Collision Avoidance System (ATP), including Q- type signaling relays, point machines, data loggers, cyber- security, embedded platforms for electronic interlocking & safety systems. The KAVACH system was conceptualized in 2012 as a train collision avoidance system (TCAS); draft specifications came in 2013, and it was commercialized in 2020.

A key imperative of KAVACH is the specification of tendering, including orders being awarded by India's railway Research Designs & Standards Organisation (RDSO) for design, development, supply, and trial of TCAS with multi- vendor interoperability features to avoid single agency dependency and to promote competition, enabling equal footing for all the relevant players with capabilities. Only select Indian manufacturers that have the required capabilities and that have displayed commercialization of the same can participate in KAVACH tenders. The said manufacturers should have carried out design & development of software- embedded control systems with its field trials in Train Protection or in Train Collision Avoidance or be an indigenous manufacturer of software- embedded Railway Signaling products such as Electronic Interlocking (EI), Single Section Digital Axle Counter (SSDAC), Multi Section Digital Axle Counter (MSDAC), data loggers for logging signaling events, Solid State Block Proving Axle Counter (SSBPAC) and Universal Fail- Safe Block Interface (UFSBI).

Scope of business: KAVACH has to be deployed across India's rail network ( \(\sim 68,000\) track km length & 7,349 railway stations) and its locomotives ( \(\sim 15,200\) units) retrofitted with electronic configuration required for the exchange of signaling information between station interlocking and locomotive over a radio network using five spot frequencies in the Ultra High Frequency range. Rollout of KAVACH will be in phases:

- Phase 1 
-High-density routes with automatic block signaling and centralized traffic control;- Phase 2 
-Heavily used networks with automatic block signaling and centralized traffic control;- Phase 3 
-Other high-density routes with automatic block signaling.

Current status: As of March 2025, Indian Railways has deployed KAVACH across 5,856km, 708 stations, 1,107 locomotives (Press Trust of India). In our view, the addressable market for KAVACH stands at \(\sim \mathrm{Rs}400\mathrm{bn}\) and includes track and locomotives. Key companies operating in this segment include CGPIs GGT, HBL Power Systems, Kernex Microsystems, Medha Servo Drives, Siemens, and QFTL. They are all approved OEM vendors of Indian Railways. CGPI management targets \(20\%\) market share in KAVACH over the next decade.

Exports strategy: CGPI has International Railway Industry Standard (IRIS) certification, and it recently obtained Association of American Railroads (AAR) certification for the US market. Recently (August 2025), CGPI entered into an agreement with Flanders Electric Motors (US; a global leader in electrical rotating equipment and technology solutions) to leverage local capabilities providing competitive pricing and faster turnaround times to the US railway sector. Per CGPI, the US market for railway traction motor replacements and refurbishments is substantial given the US's wide rail network (3x larger vs Indian Railways). Thus far, it has supplied >300 traction motors. As part of its export strategy, CGPI developed the 380V AC trailable point machine for Malaysian Railways, marking a significant step in strengthening its footprint in Southeast Asia. Simultaneously, CGPI has initiated the development of an isolation amplifier for the US rail market, expanding its presence in North America and aligning with its vision to diversify offerings and deepen engagement in advanced global rail systems.

In F15, CGPI de- merged its consumer electrical business from Crompton Greaves Ltd with a sale to private equity investors. In C19, CGPI strategically re- entered the FMEG market, launching pumps and industrial exhausts. Building on this momentum, it expanded its portfolio with a diverse range of fans and water heaters, and in March 2025 it introduced a new line of air coolers. In recent years, CGPI has deepened its presence across central and western India in the pump segment, while continuing to expand in northern and eastern markets. In the electrical consumer durables (ECD) segment, the company strengthened its e- commerce footprint and appointed channel partners in the southern region.

In F25, CGPI's consumer products division delivered strong growth with market share gains. It launched \(>50\) new SKUs and expanded its presence across e- commerce platforms, regional chain stores, and national modern retail formats. With an increasing network of over 300 authorized service centres and \(85\%\) turnaround time (TAT) adherence, the business continues to prioritize after- sales services as a critical pillar for consumer satisfaction. From a TAM standpoint, the Indian pumps, fans, and water heater markets stand at US \(1bn, US\) 125mn, and US \(125mn, respectively, as per CGPI QIP document.

Understanding competitive intensity in motors: Motors as a segment remains highly competitive, given high bargaining power with buyers mainly of low tension motors, where product differentiation is relatively low compared to medium/high tension motors. In addition, recently there have been large capacity additions by both small- mid and large players, mainly in low tension motors. This, coupled with many players reducing their prices to protect market share, has led to pricing pressure in the industry.

In our view, amongst its listed domestic peers in the capital goods industry, ABB India draws close comparison to CGPI given the overlap in the motors business (motion segment for ABB India). Other peers are smaller, do not have a complete or welldiversified product range; some are private or unlisted. ABB's motion segment primarily caters to electric motors, drives, generators, services, and integrated digital powertrain solutions, while CGPI's industrial vertical includes motors, drives and automation, railways, and consumer products.

Comparing the respective segments, we find that ABB was the largest supplier of drives and motors in C24 in value terms (Source: ABB India Annual Report). Moreover, ABB's motors sales has a higher skew of IE3 and IE4 motors (in C24, \(\sim 55\%\) of its order inflows were IE3 and IE4). ABB India is also expanding its IE4 portfolio (premium range). On the other hand, CGPI has strong market positioning in low tension motors and is expanding its portfolio in premium motors (NEMA range). Over F19- 24, ABB India's order book/inflows in the motion segment delivered \(15\% /17\%\) CAGRs, compared to \(4\% /8\%\) CAGRs in CGPI's industrial segment.

On margins, ABB India delivered segment EBIT margins of \(\sim 19 - 20\%\) on average in Q1F24- Q1F26, compared to \(12 - 13\%\) for CGPI. We think CGPI's lower margin can be largely attributed to a) higher exposure of LT motors business (pricing pressure, high competitive intensity) & perhaps marginally lower IE4 share, b) lower share of drives, c) export contribution is higher for ABB's motion division when compared to CGPI's Industrials division, d) margin dilution on account of increasing railways share in the business and lower margin in rail legacy orders (price variation clause), and e) periodic strategic
investment to ramp up the FMEG/consumer business.

CGPI manufactures transformers and switchgear equipment for the power generation, transmission, and distribution industries. It also offers turnkey solutions for T&D through sub- station projects and as an engineering, procurement, and construction (EPC) services provider.

1. Transformers: CGPI manufacturers power transformers ( \(>220 \text{kV}\) ), distribution transformers (less than or equal to \(220 \text{kV}\) ), low power transformers, locomotive transformers, cast resin transformers, solar transformers, and green transformers.  
2. Switchgears: CGPI manufactures extra-high-voltage and medium-voltage switchgear products, such as SF6 circuit breakers ( \(72 \text{kV}\) to \(420 \text{kV}\) ), surge arrestors ( \(3.3 \text{kV}\) to \(800 \text{kV}\) ), condenser bushings (oil impregnated), and current transformers ( \(33 \text{kV}\) to \(800 \text{kV}\) ). It also manufactures medium-voltage switchgears, such as indoor air insulated switchgears, outdoor breakers, and gas-insulated switchgears. Further, it has received approval from Indian railways to supply \(40 \text{kV}\) lightning arrestors for "Vande Bharat" locomotives.

Capacity addition plans across key products: 1) CGPI has expanded its power transformer capacity from 12,000 MVA to 19,500 MVA over the past three years. It plans to increase this to 40,000 MVA by September 2025 and to 85,000MAA by F28 (or \(\sim 5x\) vs F25 capacity); 2) In distribution transformers, CGPI is expanding its capacity by 3000MVA (F25: \(90\%\) utilization) to 9900MVA, with an investment of Rs400mn; and 3) CGPI is also expanding its switchgear capacity at its Nashik plant (investment: Rs1.56bn).

The order books of most larger players are locked in for the next 18- 24 months, creating a supply shortfall. We believe larger companies with capacity and capabilities stand to benefit. CGPI has less than \(10\%\) market share in transformers, coupled with capacity additions over the next couple of years providing ample growth headroom. There have been a series of announcements for new transformer capacity expansions from major global players, but there are supply- side constraints on material, equipment, and skilled labor, thus driving lead times higher for both AC & DC transformers (i.e., a more acute shortage). We note that companies must also navigate the evolving tariff situation in this multipolar world to increase their export footprints.

Improved profitability for the sector in the past three years: Considering the current supply- demand dynamics, the transformers market is turning out to be a suppliers market, in our view. The wait times highlighted by some competitors are about 4.0- 4.5 years in the international market, thereby creating opportunity for growth at reasonably high profitability for players looking to add capacity. As part of strategic diversification, CGPI has entered: a) semiconductor manufacturing - it is setting up an OSAT plant, and b) semiconductor design - it acquired the radio frequency component business of Renesas Electronics America Inc.

OSAT project details: CGPI's OSAT plant (Rs76bn; capacity: 15mn chips/day), spread across 28 acres in Sanand, Gujarat, will be executed in two phases, 1) Mini plant (peak capacity: 0.5mn unit/day; operational by: C26), and 2) Mega plant (peak capacity: 14.5mn units/day; operational by: end- C26). The company plans to manufacture a wide product range, from legacy (including quad flat no- lead (QFN) and quad flat package (QFP)) to advanced packages (e.g., flip- chip ball grid array (FC BGA) and flip- chip chip- scale package (FC CSP)). These packages cater to the automotive, consumer, industrial, and 5G industries.

Project partners: Renesas (Japan), with a \(6.8\%\) stake, and Stars Microelectronics (Thailand), with a \(0.9\%\) stake, are CGPI's technology and joint venture partners for this venture. Renesas will provide technology for packages, including QFP, wire- bond ball grid array, FC BGA and FC CSP, while Stars Micro will provide technology for legacy packages (QFN, small outline package/small outline integrated circuit). Both partners will offer training and support to set up, qualify, and ramp- up the OSAT facility.

Renesas Electronics - A pioneer in micro- controllers: Renesas was established in 2002 as a JV between NEC Electronics & Renesas Technology (a spin- off from the semi business of Hitachi & Mitsubishi Electric). Renesas has grown through strategic acquisitions, including Intersil in 2017 (which provided Renesas access to capabilities in analog & power management technologies). Renesas is focussed on specialized chips and operates 12 semiconductor facilities. It is a key player in microcontrollers (capacity: 3.5bn units p.a.), analog, power, and system- on- chip products, all components that serve a broad spectrum of applications spanning automotive, industrial, and consumer electronics. Renesas is involved in both the front- and back- end stages of the semiconductor process, from chip design and wafer fabrication to assembly, testing, and packaging.

Stars Microelectronics - expanding into advanced packaging: Stars (established in 2003) is a key player in electronics manufacturing services and in the OSAT industry. Its core business is backed by legacy packaging such as die attach, wire bonding, molding, etc. It is expanding its capabilities in advanced packaging technologies, such as flipchip and system- in- package (SiP) to meet the growing demand of the semiconductor market.

How we think the venture could benefit: CGPI has a proven track record in manufacturing, a longstanding experience in running operations in India, and it qualified to receive a government subsidy for the OSAT venture. Renesas is known for its strong positioning in microcontroller & power management ICs and has a strong global presence. We think that these attributes can complement CGPI's product portfolio and help in getting customer introductions in international markets. Star could help the venture with access to advanced technologies for flipchip and SiP technologies Thus, the venture can leverage Star's expertise in high- precision assembly and testing services and thus ensure
final products meet the rigorous quality standards.
Exhibit 68: OSAT: Manufacturing process

CGPI's OSAT financials: From a funding standpoint, we think CGPI benefits from government subsidy (50% capex incentive by the Centre). Additionally, it expects to garner \(\sim 20\%\) subsidy from the Gujarat government. CGPI will infuse an equity investment of Rs17bn (invested: Rs6.4bn till June 2025), while Renesas & Star will invest \(\sim \mathrm{Rs}1.4\mathrm{bn}\) with the balance funded through debt; we assume debt proportion equivalent to \(\sim 10\%\) of project cost. We expect asset turns of \(1.9x\) in CGPI's OSAT business on a steady- state basis \(\sim \mathrm{F3le}\) ), as we forecast revenues of Rs48bn, EBITDA margins to improve from \(16\%\) in F27 to \(19\%\) in F31e and PBT margins of \(11\%\) by F31e (in- line with management's guidance). We also assume net working capital of 80 days.

a) Motors: CGPI's focus is on strengthening its international presence and customer service capabilities. Having recently set up a regional office in Dubai, it aims to further enhance its presence in the Middle East and Africa for closer customer engagement. The company aims to tap into emerging opportunities in the global market through localized support to give its customers faster services.

CGPI aims to leverage product branding and contract manufacturing to enhance its offering in the US, since its premium range of motors and alternators, including NEMA range, as well as IE3 and IE4 motors are already available in these regions. CGPI has also advanced in the Middle East and Turkey through direct sales and distribution channels. For conventional motors, CGPI is setting up service centres in the international markets to enhance its after-sales services.

b) Drives and automation: Backed by a network of global partners, CGPI has expanded into the Middle East and South America, and now targets to strengthen its distribution network (direct/channel partners) in France and North America. It expects continued traction in exports, strengthened by authorized service partners, distributors, and a dedicated workforce of 148 employees across Europe.

c) Transformers: Transformers currently form a large part of CGPI's exports. The company aims to further expand its presence in Africa, Southeast Asia, North America, Latin America, and locally. CGPI sees recent order wins from Africa, Nepal, and UAE as proxies for the company's sustained international growth.

d) Switchgears: CGPI has made inroads in Europe's transmission system operator (TSO) grid, while expanding its presence for system house for HV switchgears. CGPI is also looking to further enhance its presence in the Middle East, Northern Europe, Brazil, Israel, and Tunisia. In the EHV segment, the company has developed 800kV and 420kV SF6 gas circuit breakers, which target the domestic and European markets.

e) Railways: CGPI aims to strengthen its footprint in Southeast Asia (it developed the 380V AC trailable point machine for Malaysian Railways). It also aims to further diversify its offerings, expand its presence in North America, and deepen its engagement in advanced global rail systems on the back of recent developments in its Isolation Amplifier for the US rail market. CGPI is currently an approved supplier of point machines and relays (it secured new orders from Bangladesh Railways in March 2025). It has also supplied point machines for field trials to Malaysian Railways to establish credentials in main line. The company developed DC traction motors for the export market in F24 to enhance its presence in the growing traction motor market.
We provide a timeline of the company's turnaround below:

Late 2019- 20: Poor management by its then promoter, Avantha Group, led to rising debt at CGPI, a halt in production, allegations of financial irregularities (including understated liabilities), and governance issues.

September 2020: Murugappa Group, via its subsidiary Tube Investments, acquired a 56% stake in CGPI. The new promoters infused Rs7bn in equity into CGPI, and CGPI's management was able to renegotiate terms with its lenders. The company was also able to navigate through Covid- 19 as it recommended operations. Senior management focussed on dealing with external stakeholders, delegating responsibility of the day- to- day operations to its business team.

October 2021: CGPI completed recasting of accounts with a restated balance sheet. Management also learned lean- manufacturing techniques and spread Six Sigma training and practices throughout the company. Its initial focus on stabilization and eventual transformation resulted in regaining lost market share.
F23: CGPI paid dividends to it shareholders, the first time in eight years.

Working capital: CGPI's working capital days has increased in the last three years from 20 days in F22 to 47 days in F25, mainly driven by a decrease in the payable days. Despite the increase in working capital, we find that CGPI's net working capital is comparable to that of its large listed capital goods peers in India. Also, CGPI's cash flow conversion (OCF/ EBITDA) was \(\sim 72\%\) in F25, in- line with that of its large listed capital goods peers in India.

Balance sheet: CGPI has invested Rs14bn in its core business and is adding capacity across motors (LV & HV), transformers (PT & DT) and switchgears. Further, CGPI plans to invest Rs10.6bn (of its total equity stake of Rs17bn) over F26- 27 to build its OSAT plant. Management estimates asset turns of 6- 8x in its core business, which, coupled with steady margins in industrials and modest improvement in power system margins, implies strong earnings visibility for the next couple of years. Thus, we expect operating cash flow to remain strong, which, coupled with cash in hand (+QIP proceeds: Rs30bn (at Rs660/ share)), should be more than enough to fund CGPI's capex needs (core business + semis business).

Open to inorganic growth: As a stated objective, CGPI is open to organic capex in its core business, and it also aims to build a semiconductor design platform through the inorganic route. Early this year, CGPI acquired a controlling stake in G.G.Tronics and Axiro (Renesas' former RF business). In evaluating inorganic growth opportunities, CGPI has stated that it considers 1) the skills of the management team, 2) operation scale, 3) technological capability, 4) product portfolio, 5) customer base, and 6) end- market exposure.

We initiate coverage on CGPI with an Overweight rating and a price target of Rs799 (15% upside potential). At our price target the stock would trade at \(62x\) Sep- 27e P/E (at an 11% discount to its three- year average). We value the stock using a sum- of- the- parts (SOTP) methodology and apply 10%, 85% and 5% probability weights to our bull, base, and bear case scenarios. The higher probability to our bull case reflects our assumption of stronger demand for transformers, recovery in the motors business, and improved execution in the railways business.

- Core business: We value the core business using forward P/E (in line with how we value other capital goods stocks under our coverage) and apply respective P/E multiples of 60x, 70x, and 50x on Sep-27e core business EPS (ex of OSAT) in our bull, base, and bear case scenario values. Our base case P/E multiple is in-line with the MNC peer average (since August 2021), our bull case P/E multiple is one standard deviation above the MNC peer group average, and our bear case P/E multiple is one standard deviation below the MNC peer group average. CGPI has historically traded broadly in-line with its MNC peers given its strong market positioning, well-diversified business mix, and strong cash flow conversion.- Semis business: We value the semiconductors business (OSAT, where there is one-time government capital subsidy involved & RF - semis design business) using discounted cash flow (DCF) methodology. Key DCF assumptions in our base case scenario include a Ke of 12.4% (beta: 1x, RF: 6.4%, Rm: 6%) and a terminal growth rate of 3%.

- Power segment: We assume demand remains robust, driving 40% revenue and 48% EBIT CAGRs, F25-28e, and EBIT margin to expand to 22.5% by F28e (vs 19% in F25).- Industrial segment: We assume stronger recovery in motors (vs our base case) and step up in execution and ordering in the railways business, driving 19% revenue and 22% EBITs CAGRs, F25-28e, and EBIT margin to expand to 12.3% by F28e (vs 11.6% in F25).- We value the core business at 70x fwd P/E, one standard deviation above the MNC peer average.- Semis: We assume asset turns (net of government subsidy) of 2.1x by F31e, EBITDA margins steadily improve from 16% in F26e to 21% in F31e, and net working capital days of 60 days. We value the semis business at 3.5x equity invested by CGPI by F27e.- We forecast consolidated revenue, EBITDA, and PAT to rise at 34%, 43%, and 40% CAGRs, F25-28e, respectively.

- Power segment: We expect demand to remain robust, driving \(35\%\) revenue and \(42\%\) EBIT CAGRs, F25-28e, and EBIT margin to expand to \(22\%\) by F28e (F25: \(19\%\) ).- Industrial segment: We expect recovery in the motors business and continued momentum in railways business execution and ordering, driving \(14\%\) revenue and \(15\%\) EBIT CAGRs, F25-28e, and EBIT margin to expand to \(11.8\%\) by F28e (vs \(11.6\%\) in F25).- We value the core business at a 60x fwd P/E, in-line with the MNC peer group average.- Semis: We expect asset turns (net of government subsidy) of \(1.9x\) by F31e, EBITDA margins steadily improve from \(16\%\) in F26e to \(19\%\) in F31e, and net working capital days of 80 days. We value the semis business using DCF methodology with a Ke of \(12.4\%\) (Beta: 1, RF: \(6.4\%\) , Rm: \(6\%\) ) and a terminal growth rate of \(3\%\) .- We forecast consolidated revenue, EBITDA, and PAT to rise at \(29\%\) , \(37\%\) , and \(34\%\) CAGRs, F25-28e, respectively.

- Power segment: We assume increased competition leads to moderating growth and profitability, driving \(30\%\) revenue and \(35\%\) EBIT CAGRs, F25-28e, and EBIT margin to expand to \(21.5\%\) by F28e (F25: \(19\%\) ).- Industrial segment: We assume a sluggish demand environment and pricing pressure in the motors business as well as tepid execution and ordering in the railways business, driving \(9\%\) revenue and \(8\%\) EBITs CAGRs, F25-28e, and EBIT margin to deteriorate to \(11.3\%\) by F28e (vs \(11.6\%\) in F25).- We value the core business at a 50x fwd P/E, one standard deviation below the MNC peer group average.- Semis: We assume asset turns (net of government subsidy) of \(1.5x\) by F31e, EBITDA margins remains flat at \(16\%\) between F26-F31e, and net working capital days of 100 days. Introduction: CG Power and Industrial Solutions Ltd. (CGPI) is an engineering conglomerate and a part of the Murugappa Group. Over seven decades, CGPI has remained a market pioneer in the electrical energy space with strong manufacturing prowess in India and overseas. It primarily manufactures equipment for the power transmission and distribution sectors, with products ranging from extra high voltage and medium voltage switchgears and transformers (power/distribution), air insulated and gas insulated, indoor and outdoor switchgears. Additionally, it provides turnkey solutions for substations, power quality solutions, and automation solutions.

CGPI changed leadership hands as Tube Investments, a Murugappa Group company, took over in November 2020. Murugappa Group is a 123- year old conglomerate with a presence in India and internationally. The group has nine listed companies under its gamut - - Carborundum Universal, CGPI, Cholamandalam Financial Holdings, Cholamandalam Investment & Finance, Cholamandalam MS General Insurance, Coromandel International Limited, EID Parry, Shanthi Gears, Tube Investment of India and Wendt (India) Ltd.

Key business segments: CGPI has two business segments, Power Systems and Industrial. It manufactures a wide range of induction motors, drives, transformers, traction motors, propulsion systems, signalling relays, etc. To further strengthen its capability in rail signalling, in August 2024 CGPI acquired a majority stake in G.G. Tronics, which specializes in electronic safety systems (KAVACH, an Automatic Train Protection system). As part of its strategy to diversify into semiconductors, CGPI started setting up an outsourced semiconductor assembly and test (OSAT) facility in February 2024 to manufacture legacy and advanced packages. In October 2024 it acquired the radio frequency components business of Renesas Electronics America to expand into semiconductor design. Recently, it has re- forayed into consumer appliances such as fans, pumps, and water heaters.

Power systems business segment: CGPI manufactures transformers and switchgear equipment for the power generation, transmission, and distribution industries. It also offers turnkey solutions for T&D through sub- station projects and as an engineering, procurement, and construction (EPC) services provider.

1. Transformers: CGPI manufacturers power transformers (>220 kV), distribution transformers (less than or equal to 220 kV), low power transformers, locomotive transformers, cast resin transformers, solar transformers, and green transformers.  
2. Switchgears: CGPI manufactures extra-high-voltage and medium-voltage switchgear products, such as SF6 circuit breakers (72kV to 420 kV), surge arrestors (3.3kV to 800 kV), condenser bushings (oil impregnated), and current transformers (33 kV to 800 kV). It also manufactures medium-voltage switchgears, such as indoor air insulated switchgears, outdoor breakers, and gas-insulated switchgears. Further, it has received approval from Indian railways to supply 40kV lightning arrestors for "Vande Bharat" locomotives.

1. Motors: CGPI manufactures a range of low-tension (LT) motors (F24 domestic market share: \(38\%\) in value terms), high-tension (HT) motors, fractional horsepower (FHP) motors, and stampings.  
2. Drives and automation: CGPI manufactures a wide range of drives and automation products to enhance industrial efficiency and control. CGPI's products include alternating current (AC) drives, direct current (DC) low-voltage drives, and medium-voltage drives, which are used to regulate motor speed and torque for optimized performance, as well as soft starters and shaft power monitors to ensure smooth operation and protect equipment.  
3. Railways: CGPI manufactures rolling stock products signalling products. Rolling stock products include propulsion systems for diesel and electric locomotives, traction motors, traction converters, auxiliary converters, train control monitoring system (TCMS), battery chargers, and electrics for multiple-unit trains, as well as signalling products that include relays, train collision avoidance system (TCAS) and multi section digital axle counter system (MSDAC).  
4. FMEG: CGPI entered the fast-moving electrical goods (FMEG) segment with pumps exhaust fans, and subsequently expanded into ceiling, table, pedestal, and wall fans, as well as instant and storage water heaters.

CGPI has gained meaningful momentum towards sustainability; many of its facilities have achieved certifications for zero waste to landfill, single- use plastic elimination, and zero liquid discharge. It has managed to reduce the total emission intensity of its Scope 1 and Scope 2 emissions by \(9\%\) in F25, vs F24, and has committed to become carbon neutral (for Scope 1 and Scope 2) by 2030.

Carbon footprint reduction: CGPI is actively implementing strategies to minimize its carbon footprint, such as enhancing its renewable energy inputs and by switching to less carbon fuel. Its share of renewable energy consumption relative to total energy usage was at \(11.5\%\) in F25, and targets to increase it further.

Hazardous materials: Given the industry's nature, the product life cycles at CGPI typically extend beyond 20- 25 years. As a result, CGPI does not reclaim its products at the end of their life. However, the company is finding ways to collaborate with its value chain partners to explore a safe and sustainable end- of- life treatment for its products.

Greenhouse emissions: At its Switchgear division, CGPI uses SF6 in some Switchgear- related products. Although it is an effective insulating gas, SF6 is a potent greenhouse gas with very high Global Warming Potential (GWP). Recognizing its environmental impact, CGPI is proactively exploring and implementing alternative technologies that offer comparable performance with significantly reduced environmental consequences.
